channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukrainians Recount Frantic Russian Retreat
item.description: Residents of towns recently retaken by Ukraine described a chaotic flight by disorganized Russian troops, suggesting morale and inexperience remain major problems for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: During a media tour arranged by the Ukrainian government of recently retaken territory, a vehicle used by Russian forces stood on the road outside Balakliya.

item.title: Russia Secretly Gave $300 Million to Political Parties and Officials Worldwide, U.S. Says
item.description: A U.S. intelligence review found that Russian agencies and figures aimed to exert political influence abroad and sway elections on behalf of the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

item.title: Stocks Plunge as Inflation Data Undercuts Wall Street’s Optimism
item.description: Stocks plunged, government bond yields soared and the dollar bounced after investors were wrong-footed by a report showing stubbornly high price increases last month.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Britain’s Inflation Rate Slows Slightly to 9.9 Percent
item.description: But prices are still rising at about the fastest pace in 40 years and an increase in core inflation will keep the pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: A food shopper in London. Inflation in Britain is the highest in 40 years.

item.title: Asian stock markets fall in early trading.
item.description: Major indexes fell in early trading across the Asia Pacific region on Wednesday, a day after U.S. stocks plummeted.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: To Make Money in the Stock Market, Do Nothing
item.description: The bear market endures, yet the S&P 500 index rose more than 17 percent from mid-June to mid-August. Don’t even try to guess what will happen next, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: Ken Starr, Independent Counsel in Clinton Investigation, Dies at 76
item.description: Mr. Starr’s investigation into President Clinton’s affair with a former White House intern propelled issues of sex and morality to the center of American life for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Ken Starr uncovered President Bill Clinton’s affair with a White House intern.

item.title: Biden Flies Home to Wilmington to Vote in Delaware Primary
item.description: The president and the first lady arrived in Delaware shortly before polls closed to cast their votes in Tuesday’s primary election.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:description: President Biden after voting on Tuesday. The trip had not been on his publicly released schedule.

item.title: King Charles and Camilla Visit Northern Ireland Ahead of Queen’s Funeral
item.description: King Charles III visited Belfast and met with members of Sinn Fein, the Irish nationalist party, now the largest in the country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: King Charles III and Camilla viewing floral tributes left outside Hillsborough Castle in Belfast, Northern Ireland, on Tuesday.

item.title: When the Queen Died, Someone Had to Tell the Bees
item.description: A report that the royal beekeeper had informed Queen Elizabeth II’s bees of her death received some mockery, but it has been a tradition for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Firefighters Gain Ground on Mosquito Fire in Northern California
item.description: The Mosquito fire in the Sierra Nevada foothills neared Foresthill on Tuesday after cautious optimism that firefighters were gaining control.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:credit: Jungho Kim for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighter monitoring a portion of the Mosquito fire that flared up on Tuesday near Foresthill, Calif.

item.title: How to Save a Forest by Burning It
item.description: Prescribed burns are key to reducing the risk of catastrophic wildfires. Scientists are using high-tech tools to ensure they can be done safely in a warming world.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Andri Tambunan
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times

item.title: Republicans Struggle to Unite Party Around National Abortion Restrictions
item.description: A new proposal was intended to align Republicans on abortion policy before the midterm elections. It only exposed divisions.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham introducing a Republican abortion bill at the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: West Virginia Passes Strict Abortion Ban
item.description: The bill, which has some exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the mother, will go into effect immediately if the governor signs it.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Kristian Thacker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The West Virginia Senate and House of Delegates came to an agreement on Tuesday after disagreeing on an abortion bill in July.

item.title: After Trump Associates’ Subpoenas, Notes of Caution About Jan. 6 Inquiry
item.description: The criminal inquiry into Donald Trump’s efforts to reverse the outcome of the 2020 election appears to be accelerating, but prosecutors are said to be a long way from making any decisions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: The Justice Department is carrying out two distinct criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Godard Taught Me How to Watch Cinema, Even as He Kept Reinventing It
item.description: Jean-Luc Godard was a prophet of film’s future as an art form, layering images and sound that the body could sink into and the mind could puzzle through.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: Ukraine’s Achievement Is Biden’s, Too
item.description: As Russian troops flee their positions, now is the time to press the military advantage.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier waves to passing buses near the recaptured village of Verbivka, Ukraine.

item.title: Putin’s New Cold War: Freeze Europe
item.description: To defeat petro-Putinism in Europe, U.S. energy policy has to be the arsenal of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Bill Gates: ‘We’re in a Worse Place Than I Expected’
item.description: The philanthropist on how the pandemic and the effects of the war in Ukraine are setting back progress.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells

item.title: Friedrich Schelling’s Philosophy Can Help Us Through the Climate Crisis
item.description: Friedrich Schelling’s ideas might provide a foundation on which to anchor the fight for our climate and our survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Wulf

item.title: Sally Schmitt’s French Laundry
item.description: Sally Schmitt sold the French Laundry. Then it became “the best restaurant in the world.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Proudfoot

item.title: A Look at the Misery Index and Inflation
item.description: Surprise! Good news on inflation.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Quiet Quitting’ Is Not the Solution to Burnout
item.description: As counterintuitive as it seems, adding energizing activities to your schedule just might make life feel more doable.
item.dc:creator: Laura Vanderkam

item.title: The crown and climate
item.description: Britain has been one of the main contributors to global warming. We look at the new king’s environmental credentials.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Charles at the 2021 United Nations climate change conference, when he was Prince of Wales.

item.title: Did You Recently Buy an Electric Vehicle? We Want to Hear About It.
item.description: Sales of electric cars are surging as more people become interested in the technology and grow concerned about climate change.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:description: An electric vehicle charging in Los Angeles in August.

item.title: Jennifer Egan and the Goon Squad
item.description: The novelist talks about her Pulitzer-winning book, which includes one chapter written as a PowerPoint presentation, and Stephen Fry discusses Greek mythology.

item.title: Join Al Gore and John Kerry for a Times Climate Event
item.description: How does climate change exacerbate other global challenges? Join us remotely or in person for our climate event series, with an upcoming gathering in New York in September.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sandy Hook Victim’s Sister Recalls the Pain of Alex Jones’s Lies
item.description: The Infowars fabulist and his followers intensified their fear and trauma, Sandy Hook survivors say on the first day of a critical trial.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:description: Nicole Hockley, mother of Dylan Hockley, in court during the first day of the Alex Jones Sandy Hook trial on Tuesday

item.title: Package Explodes at Northeastern U. in Boston, Injuring an Employee
item.description: A second package was rendered safe by the bomb squad, and the 45-year-old victim was taken to an area hospital with a minor hand injury, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: The Boston police investigated after a package detonated at a building on the Northeastern University campus on Tuesday night, injuring an employee.

item.title: Woman Gets 4 Months After Shoving Flight Attendant, Spitting on a Passenger
item.description: Kelly Pichardo, 32, will also have to pay more than $9,000 to American Airlines for the altercation, which came as incidents involving unruly passengers unnerved airline workers and the public.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: An American Airlines flight from Dallas to Los Angeles had to be diverted to Phoenix during a February 2021 incident.

item.title: A Day of Firsts for Peltola in Congress Starts a Sprint to Another Election
item.description: Representative Mary Peltola was sworn in as the first Alaska Native and first woman to represent her state in the House. She has eight weeks before she faces voters again.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Representative Mary Peltola, a Democrat, will complete the term of Representative Don Young, a Republican who died in March. Her parents worked on Mr. Young’s first campaign.

item.title: Lymphatic Drainage: Does it Work? And How to Do It Yourself
item.description: These wellness practices — which center on one invisible network of vessels and nodes — have soared in popularity in recent years. Should you try them?
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Heather Sten for The New York Times

item.title: How to Cope With Financial Stress
item.description: Experts share tips on how to feel empowered and manage stress as prices continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Do Waist Trainers Work?
item.description: Some claim the corset-like garments help wearers slim their midsections. Here’s what the experts say.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie, Photograph by Shutterstock

item.title: How to Handle Menopause Symptoms While Working
item.description: Hot flashes, mood swings and other signs of menopause can cause women to quit their jobs. Here’s how some handle symptoms while working.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Why Did Instagram Pause This Play? Its Creators Still Don’t Know.
item.description: Marion Siéfert’s “_jeanne_dark_,” about a shy teenager beginning to express her sexuality, contains no nudity yet still ran afoul of Instagram’s opaque policies.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle
item.media:credit: Julien Mignot for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marion Siéfert wrote “_jeanne_dark_,” a pun on the French styling of Joan of Arc, based on her own stifled upbringing in a Roman Catholic family in France.
